examples.text: Be careful not to drop it; it’s very fragile.

definitions.definition: weak and uncertain; easy to destroy or harm

examples.text: In her job she was used to dealing with actors’ fragile egos.

definitions.definition: thin or light and often beautiful

examples.text: The woman's fragile face broke into a smile.

definitions.definition: not strong and likely to become ill

examples.text: Her father is now 86 and in fragile health.
I'm feeling a bit fragile after last night *(= not well, perhaps because of drinking too much alcohol)*.

wordOrigin: late 15th cent. (in the sense ‘morally weak’): from Latin fragilis, from frangere ‘to break’. The sense ‘liable to break’ dates from the mid 16th cent.
